utterances: Thank you so much.
What do you envision for how you will use the energy of these millions of people around the world?
I think that's a great question.
We have been encouraging women to march on.
That's sort of been our slogan.

But I think in order for us to actually achieve change, that will require us to ensure that we are talking to our elected officials, that we are advocating, that we are engaged civically in our communities.
And I think all of that combined is really going to create a shift in what we've seen and what we know has been happening as it pertains to women's rights.
And hopefully, as the saying goes, the future is female, and we'll see more rights achieved for women across the world.
I hear you talking about engagement but not necessarily about a specific issue.
And with so many different issues on the table represented at these marches, do you fear that a lack of focus could dissipate some of this energy?
I don't think that a lack of focus will dissipate the energy.
I think that there are a lot of issues for people to be passionate and concerned about.
I think what we saw is a need to be intersectional in how we approach our advocacy.
So it means that...
Intersectional meaning, black people advocate for LGBTQ people and...
Correct.
...Immigrants advocate for women, et cetera.
Absolutely.
Because together, if we're interwoven and interconnected in our fight for progress, it makes us stronger.

When you look at the protest movements of the last decade, from the Tea Party to the Occupy movement to Black Lives Matter, what lessons do you take away from those about what works and what doesn't work?
We, in some ways, are a leaderless movement because we have a whole group of women who had been leading this effort.
But we've had to figure out what that structure looks like and how to make that work.
I think that was sort of a lesson learned from the Occupy movement.
And I do think that this is different.
We can't just say it's a cookie-cutter-type lessons that we can learn but really looking at - what is the reality of this political climate?
And what is it that we are hearing from women about what they want to do and what they want to see changed and how we can make that happen?
What specifically is the next step?
Well, there are lots of next steps, and we encourage people to stay in touch with us.

If they weren't able to come to the march, we definitely want them to be sure to check out our website because that's going to be the place where we continue to unfold all the various actions that we'll have from here on out.
But give us a preview.
I mean, you've announced there'll be 10 actions in a hundred days.
Specifically, what's the next step?
Well, I don't want to get out ahead of myself.
And - since you've seen the website, you know that we have postcards that we are sending out to elected officials.
And we're encouraging people to march on and to continue to advocate for whatever your issue is.
Speak to your local elected officials.
Speak to your state elected official, your governor as well as the president.
We want people to connect and to advocate for themselves.
We don't want to tell people what to do.
We want people to find the issue that moves them the most and to do something about that issue in these next few days.
Ultimately, how will you measure whether this movement has been successful or not?
Well, I think it definitely is about engagement.
I think we've clearly made history.
And so that in and of itself, there's a place in the history books where this effort will be noted.

But I think for all of us, we are committed to ensuring that that's just not the end of it - that there is some actual substantive change, that we move the ball for all of the people that we march for, whether it's our mothers, our grandmothers, our daughters, our sisters, our friends or the little girls that we don't even know yet.
But we know we want to see a better future for them than the one that we're currently living in.
Janaye Ingram was head of logistics for the Women's March on Washington.
Thanks for taking the time.
Thank you.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION: SCIENCE FRIDAY.
I'm Ira Flatow.

And for the rest of the hour, a look at the state of our planet, something like an annual check up on planet Earth actually, because my next guest has been charting the relative health of Earth and its systems at least since the 1970s when he founded the Worldwatch Institute.

In his career, Lester Brown has coauthored or authored over 50 books on topics ranging from ""Who Will Feed China,"" which he wrote in the '90s, to the ""Future of the Automobile."" And those two things - feeding China, fueling our cars - are related as Lester Brown will tell you.
He's been warning all these years that if we turn corn into fuel, food prices are going to go up and they have.
He's warned us that once oil hit a $100 a barrel that would be a turning point, too.
Well, it has.
And now, what should we expect?
If I knew the answer, then I wouldn't be here.
Yeah.
That's always a very popular question that they have.
So what I do is I just pop it out for them, you know, kind of show them what it's like.
They all think it's going to be this round ball like a marble.
Mm-hmm.
And it looks more like a clamshell, the way it sits in the socket and moves with the muscles in there.
So it looks like a clamshell.
They're all blown away by that.
Mm-hmm.
I can understand why.
You have not made an effort to cover your scars.
Your hair is still cut short.
Your other eye is - well, it's closed.
You don't need medals when you got scars like mine.
People understand what you've been through.
Yeah.
You know, I wear them with pride.
There is - a lot of changes that have happened in your life as a result of your injury.
Tell us a little bit about how you lost your sight.
I was hit by a roadside bomb in Mahmoudiya, Iraq, a couple 155 millimeter artillery shells set on the roadside.
I was sitting in a machine gun turret.
I was thrown about 20 meters from the vehicle.
My forehead was crushed.
Forty-five percent of my cranium has been replaced with acrylic.
I lost both eyes.
My right hand has been completely reconstructed.
I've fractured my left patella, the kneecap bone.
I've had some soft tissue damage there, nicked my femoral artery.
I was messed up pretty bad.
A couple of times, you write in your blog, you flatlined during surgery.
I had three different surgeries that I flatlined in.
I came back.
You know, you can't keep me down.
So…
That - reading your blog, that is the one thing that emerges more strongly than ever.
All of the challenges that you face now - your medical challenges, obviously, your sight - you see them as opportunities?
Well, you know, I've been blessed with life definitely and I've been kept alive through this whole thing.
I think that because of my injuries I've sustained, a lot of opportunities have come up.
And I've been proactive in taking advantage at a lot of those.
You know, every once in a while, somebody will say something to me.
You know, hey, you should do this, or we can do this together…
Mm-hmm.
…and I'll say to myself, self, let's take them up on this.
Well, some of those things include skydiving.
I went skydiving in Belen, New Mexico, right outside Albuquerque for the - I was there for the Blinded Veterans Association national convention.
And driving a Ferrari.
And a Dodge Viper.
Cool.
Yeah.
Yeah.
We did it in a parking lot, an empty parking lot with nobody in it.
I got a lot of comments saying that I was very irresponsible when - in different things like that.
I would like everyone to know that there was somebody in the vehicle with me.
They had their hands on the stirring wheel in case anything went wrong.
We did plenty of immediate action drills beforehand to - just in case, if this goes wrong, this is what you need to do, different things like that.
Mm-hmm.
So we did it as safe as we could.
Mm-hmm.
But there has also been a price.
For one thing, when you came home, your marriage did not survive.
No, it did not.
And that's - obviously, these kinds of prices - you're hardly the only veteran to come home and have that situation.
